title-group.article-title: Dynamic model of a two-cylinder four-stroke internal combustion engine and vibration treatment

contrib-group.aff: Department of Automotive Engineering, Gazi University, Turkey

author-notes.corresp: Halit Karabulut, Department of Automotive Engineering, Technology Faculty, Gazi University, 06500 Teknikokullar Ankara, Turkey. Email: halitk@gazi.edu.tr

abstract.p: Engine vibrations of large amplitude are caused by inertial effects of the piston–crankshaft mechanism and gas forces, and are transmitted to the chassis of a vehicle in the form of periodically varying forces through the engine mounts. Both the engine vibrations and mount forces may be minimized by designing proper engine components and mounts, which requires a dynamic simulation of the engine. In this study, a three degree of freedom dynamic model, enabling the simultaneous treatment of the piston–crankshaft mechanism and engine block, was devised for a two-cylinder four-stroke engine. Periodic and temporary variations of crankshaft speed, the variation of torque and power with speed, torsional and translational vibrations of the engine block, and the variation of mount forces with respect to the damping and stiffness coefficients of the mounts were studied. The torsional and translational vibrations of the engine block were found to be mainly affected by the combustion gas force and inertia force of the reciprocating masses, respectively. A simple relation has been obtained to determine the position and mass of counterweights used for eliminating the vertical vibration of the block.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Vibration and noise are among the most significant problems of wheeled vehicles driven by piston engines. The source of noise is vibration; however, noise and vibration are treated separately. A large proportion of vehicle vibrations are induced by the engine. Among the causes of engine-induced vibrations are variable gas forces applied to the pistons, the inertial unbalance of rotating and translating components, static and elastic deflections of engine components, the off-centred rotation of the flywheel, transient contacts in the valve mechanism and timing gears, impacts due to clearances, and so on.1–4

Vibration can cause the vehicle systems to fail by inducing several physical effects, such as material fatigue, impacts, friction, heat generation, and so on. Material fatigue is among the most significant consequences of vibration.5,6 Vehicle vibration also has harmful effects on the human body. With respect to the frequency, amplitude and influencing period of the vibration, the human body experiences different degrees of physiological and psychological discomfort such as weariness, back pain, distraction, annoyance, and so on.7,8

The engine vibrations generated by different sources have different frequencies. By comparing the frequency of any vibration with the engine rotation frequency, its source can be detected.9 Vibration spectra are used for this purpose. In vibration spectra, any vibration response such as torque, force, displacement, acceleration, and so on, can be plotted against the frequency. The excitation forces generated by the inertia of reciprocating masses and the other imbalanced masses make contributions to the whole multiples of the engine order vibrations. The gas forces make contributions to both the whole and half multiples of the engine order vibrations. The smaller multiples of engine order vibrations are caused by component flexibility and other factors such as clearance, transient contacts, and so on. Simple analytic models can help pinpoint some of the frequencies observed in the spectral compositions.9

In order to avoid the transmission of the engine vibrations to the vehicle chassis, vibration isolators are used.10,11 In the literature of engine technology, the vibration isolators are named engine mounts, and most of them are made of rubber. A vehicle’s engine runs in a large speed range and generates vibrations with different frequencies. An ideal vibration isolator is expected to isolate all vibrations. A rubber mount is only able to isolate vibrations in a limited frequency range.11 Therefore, rubber mounts are designed to isolate the vibrations in a specified range of frequency. To obtain an adequate performance in larger ranges of frequency, hydraulic mounts have been developed.12,13

A dynamic model including all the dynamic components of an engine and their compliances, as well as the chassis of the vehicle, would enable a more reliable tool for the design of engine mounts. However, since the development of such a model would take a long time and considerable effort, the engine and chassis are treated separately.14–16 Even a dynamic model, including the fundamental dynamic components of the engine beside the mounts, is too complicated. Therefore, the engine mounts are mostly designed via a simplified model named a rigid-body model.14–17 In this model, the engine is assumed to be a rigid body with six degrees of freedom; three of them are translational displacements of the centre of gravity of the body according to the (x, y, z) coordinate system, the others are rotations of the body around the x, y and z axes. The amplitudes of all motions are assumed to be small enough to use linear equations in modelling. In some rigid-body approximations, predetermined excitation forces and moments, in terms of harmonic functions, were used,17,18 and the excitation forces are applied to the centre of gravity of the body. There are also rigid-body models (named fully coupled) simultaneously calculating the excitation forces and moments.19,20

In practice, none of the engine components, including the block, are rigid. The main journal bearings, crankshaft, the pistons and connecting rods are exposed to elastic deformations due to forces exerted upon them transiently.21–24 The flexible engine components, especially the crankshaft, generate some high-frequency secondary vibrations that interact with the block vibrations.

The reciprocating motion of the piston in the liner is not a one-dimensional sliding motion. Due to the clearance between the piston and its liner, about the top and bottom dead centres, the piston displays an angular motion around the gudgeon pin, which is named tilting motion.9 At the same time, the gudgeon pin and piston together perform a lateral motion in the cylinder bore from side to side. Due to the clearances between the crank pin journals and their bushing, the big-end of the connecting rod also performs secondary motions. All of these secondary motions have an influence on the vibratory motion of the engine block.

The friction forces have a profound effect on the characteristics of the engine block vibrations. Most of the engine friction occurs at the bearings, valve train and piston assembly. Experimental investigations indicate that 15–18% of the engine power is wasted by friction. Friction forces are generated by viscous shear of lubricants and the boundary interactions.25,26

Between sliding surfaces, if there is a proper lubricant film thickness, only hydrodynamic friction appears, linearly varying with the sliding velocity of the moving surface. If the lubricant film is quite thin, however, a lubrication mechanism, named boundary lubrication, takes place. This is an intermediate situation between the dry friction and hydrodynamic lubrication. In this phenomenon, metal-to-metal contact friction occurs between the asperity tips taking place on the rough surface as well as the shear stress generated by the lubricant layers in the valleys of surface topography. The shear stress generated by the lubricant layers is different from the shear stress of Newtonian fluids.26

The piston friction is estimated to be the most significant among the friction forces affecting the vibratory motion of the engine block.27 The total friction force exerted on a piston is mainly caused by skirt friction and ring-pack friction. The piston skirt and ring-pack friction comprise both the hydrodynamic and boundary friction (asperity friction). The simplest approximation used for calculating the hydrodynamic friction between piston skirt and liner is the Couette approximation.26,28 Ring-pack friction depends on many physical factors such as gas pressure, secondary motions of the piston, static and dynamic distortions of the cylinder bore, starvation of the lubricant around the ring contact surface, the nonaxisymmetrical form of rings in the cylinder bore, and so on.25,28 About the top and bottom dead centres of the piston stroke, the tilting motion of the piston generates a significant rate of increase in asperity friction.26,29 For the theoretical treatment of the piston lubrication and prediction of the piston friction, the Reynolds lubrication equation is used.9,25–29 In a four-stroke engine, the minimum lubricant film thickness and the maximum friction appears at the power stroke where the contribution of asperity friction is found to be larger than hydrodynamic friction.29 Offsets of gudgeon pin and crankshaft from the cylinder axis result in a significant reduction in piston skirt friction, as well as generating a minimal parasitic friction.26 The elastic behaviour of the piston skirt reduces the asperity friction between the piston and its liner, while increasing the hydrodynamic force supporting the piston.30 In the vibration analysis of the engine block, the hydrodynamic forces exerted on a piston can easily be taken into account by means of imposing a damping-force term in the momentum equation of the piston. However, in order to take the piston asperity friction into account, a correlation becomes necessary. For this purpose, the total asperity friction of the ring-pack was assumed to be a constant, while the skirt asperity friction is calculated via multiplying the side force with a constant determined experimentally or theoretically.27 The result is an equation of the form Q(t)=F∞+CoFS, where F∞ and FS indicate the ring-pack asperity friction and piston side force, respectively. The ring-pack asperity friction is measured under static conditions.

It is estimated that 20–30% of the total engine friction is generated by crankshaft bearings.31 Crankshafts are generally made of heat-treated hard steels. The surfaces of the crank pin journals and main journals are finished by grinding. The bearings are circular shells consisting of two half-sections placed in bores. The inner surfaces of the bearings are coated with a Babbit metal.32 Tin–aluminium and lead–bronze are the most common Babbit metals used in the automotive industry.33 Between journals and their beds, there is a certain amount of clearance for lubrication. In both the crank pin and the main journal bearings, friction is a combination of hydrodynamic and asperity friction, however, the prevalent mode of friction is hydrodynamic. The bearing friction may be predicted via the Couette approximation. However, the motion of a journal in its bearing is not a simple concentric rotation. As well as rotation, it performs periodic lateral motions. Therefore, a more accurate prediction of bearing friction may be accomplished via solving the Reynolds lubrication equation as a part of the simulation process.26,34

The present study is concerned with the dynamic modelling of a four-stroke internal combustion engine with two cylinders located side by side. Figure 1 illustrates the crankshaft of the engine where both pins are situated in the same angular position. As a result of this, the excitation frequency of both forces, inertia and gas, will be equal to the engine rotation frequency. The system has three degrees of freedom, which are torsional vibration of the block around the crankshaft centre, translational vibration of the block in the direction of the cylinder axis and the fluctuations in crankshaft speed. The dynamic model consists of planar motion equations of the pistons, connecting rods, crankshaft and engine block. The novelty presented by this paper is the inclusion of friction forces in the dynamic model. The coupled treatment of the block vibrations and crankshaft motion, as implemented in this work, is also not common practice.

sec.title: Coordinates and variables
sec.p: The coordinate systems used for the derivation of kinematic and dynamic relations are illustrated in Figure 2. Time (t) is the independent variable of the analysis. The crankshaft angle (θ), displacement of the crankshaft centre (yc) and the angular displacement of the engine block around the crankshaft centre (φ) are the dependent variables of the analysis. Displacements of piston-1(y) and piston-2 (ϒ), and the angles made by the piston connecting rods with the cylinder axis (β) and (ϑ) are kinematic functions.

caption.p: Comparison of the static position and any instantaneous position of the system.

sec.p: Before motion starts, piston-1 is at the top dead centre of its stroke. Displacements of piston-1(y) and piston-2 (ϒ) are measured from the top dead centres while the system is static. The angular displacement of the engine block (φ) is measured from the static position of the cylinder axis. The angular displacement of the crankshaft is measured from the upward direction of the cylinder axis. The static location of the crankshaft centre is assumed to be the reference point of the translational displacement of the block (yc).

sec.title: Assumptions
sec.p: Pistons, connecting rods, the crankshaft and the engine block are assumed to be rigid bodies. The engine is assumed to be mounted on a rigid base with rubber mounts. The friction appearing at the piston–liner conjunction is assumed to be a combination of hydrodynamic shear and asperity friction. In bearing friction, the contribution of hydrodynamic shear is considered, but asperity is ignored. The offset between the cylinder axis and gudgeon pin axis is disregarded, as well as the offset between the cylinder axis and crankshaft axis. The mass inertia moments of the crankshaft and flywheel are combined as a unique value. All the secondary motions occurring in the block are disregarded. Ring friction is assumed to be constant. The stiffness and damping coefficient of the mounts are constant. The properties of the lubricant do not vary. Gas forces do not change from cylinder to cylinder or from cycle to cycle. The friction between the gudgeon pin and its bore is disregarded. The effect of gravity is also ignored. The mass of the connecting rod is split into a part reciprocating with the piston and a part rotating with the crank pin. The mass of the part reciprocating with the piston is assumed to be one-third of the connecting rod mass. The crankshaft is assumed to be balanced.

sec.title: Equations of motion
sec.p: The comparison of the static and any instantaneous positions of the piston–crankshaft assembly is shown in Figure 2. According to Figure 2, the displacements of the pistons are
The angles made by piston connecting rods with the cylinder axis are

The position of any one of the pistons at any instant may be illustrated as shown in Figure 3. The stroke direction of the pistons makes an angle ϕ with the y axis. The forces exerted on piston-1 are: the pressure force of the working gas (FW), the pressure force of the crankcase (FCH), the dry friction force between the cylinder wall and side surface of piston-1 (Fu), the side force exerted by the cylinder wall (Fs), the force applied by the connecting rod (FL) and the hydrodynamic force caused by the damping effect of the lubricant (Fμ1). The forces exerted on piston-2 may be written in the same order: FG, FCH, Fr, Fδ, FMand Fμ2. The motion equations of the pistons are

caption.p: An instantaneous position of the piston and forces exerted on it.

sec.p: From equation (5), by ignoring the inertia and viscous damping terms, the side force exerted on piston-1 is obtained as
From equation (6), the axial force appearing on the piston connecting rod of piston-1 is obtained as
Similarly, from equations (7) and (8), the side force and the connecting rod force exerted on piston-2 are obtained as
The asperity friction forces exerted on piston-1 and piston-2 may be described as27

In equations (13) and (14), F∞ is a constant friction force generated by the piston rings. The big-end of the piston connecting rod performs a circular motion together with the crank pin, while the other end performs a translational motion with the piston pin. The inertia force generated by the connecting rod in the direction of piston motion is taken into account by means of adding one-third of the connecting rod mass to the piston mass. The other component of the connecting rod inertia force is calculated approximately via the equation of angular motion around the piston pin.20,35 The angular motion equations of the connecting rods may be set as
where Fβ and Fϑ are the tangential forces applied to the big-end of the connecting rods by crank pins and are illustrated in Figure 4.

caption.p: Forces contributing to the angular momentum of the crankshaft and direction angles.

sec.p: While the crank pin rotates in the big-end bearing, a siding motion occurs between the bearing and pin surfaces. This sliding motion induces a hydrodynamic moment proportional to the sliding speed. This moment is balanced by a reaction force applied by the engine block to the thrust surface of the piston.
With respect to the crank centre, the reaction forces exerted on the thrust surface of the pistons induce the moments
where the distance between the centre of the gudgeon pin and the crankshaft centre is assumed to be the moment arm.

The forces and moments contributing to the angular motion of the crankshaft are: the axial forces appearing on the connecting rods (FL) and (FM), tangential forces (Fβ) and (Fϑ), moment of external load (MQ), start-up moment (MS), moment of hydrodynamic friction appearing on the main journals (Mμ) and the moments of hydrodynamic friction appearing on the crank pins (Mν1) and (Mν2). The directions of these moments and forces are illustrated in Figure 4. The angular motion equation of the crankshaft may be written as

The forces and moments contributing to the torsional vibration of the engine block are: piston side forces (FS) and (Fδ), the total of hydrodynamic friction moments appearing in the main journals (Mμ), moments caused by the crank pin’s hydrodynamic friction (Mν1) and (Mν2), start-up moment (MS), moment of the torsional spring and the moment of the torsional damper (Figure 5). The torsional spring and damper considered here are imaginary elements considered on behalf of the engine mounts. The angular motion equation of the block is

caption.p: An instantaneous position of the engine block, forces and moments contributing to its momentum equation of angular motion.

sec.p: Figure 5 illustrates the relations between the torsional and translational motions of the engine block and the deformations of the mounts. The moments of the imaginary torsional spring and torsional damper should be equal to those of the engine mounts. From this condition, the relations between the constants of the imaginary torsional spring and damper, and the engine mounts are stated as
respectively.

Forces with a contribution to the translational vibration of the engine block are: working gas pressure forces (FW) and (FG), crank case pressure (FCH), the connecting rod axial forces (FL) and (FM), piston skirt asperity friction forces (Fu) and (Fr), hydrodynamic friction forces appearing between pistons and cylinders, the centrifugal forces generated by the counterweight masses taking part on the crankshaft and damping and spring forces considered as the equivalent of mounts. The translational motion equation of the block is
The mass of the engine block (me) includes all of the masses except the piston mass. Despite that, the use of the total mass of the engine is not disadvantageous.
The equivalent spring and damper constants used in equation (23) may be defined, in terms of the mount constants, as
For a simple mounting model as illustrated in Figure 5, the displacement of the mounts can be defined as
where the mounts are symmetrically situated at both sides of the engine block on a line passing through the crankshaft centre. The mount forces of this simple mounting model can be expressed as

The variation of working gas pressure was experimentally obtained from a single-cylinder, four-stroke diesel engine.36 To enable the use of data in the computerization of the dynamic model, it was extrapolated with the Fourier series

The values of Ak and Bk are tabulated in Table 1. In Figure 6, a comparison of extrapolation to the original data is illustrated, where the grey thick line indicates the original data and the dark thin line indicates the extrapolation.

sec.p: The initial conditions to be used for equations (19), (20) and (23) are

sec.title: Method of solution
sec.p: The solution of the dynamic model was obtained via an iterative prediction correction algorithm. By means of substituting the initial values, given by equations (31a–f), into the kinematic relations (1) to (4), the initial values of y, ϒ, β and ϑ were calculated. After getting the relevant relations from equations (1) to (4) by deriving them, the initial values of y·, ϒ·, β·, ϑ·, y··, ϒ··, β··, ϑ··, y…, ϒ…, β… and ϑ… were calculated by means of substituting the initial conditions given by equations (31a–f). When conducting the calculations, the use of all of the relations derived throughout this analysis were required, as well as their derivatives. Since the modelling equations are non-linear and interrelated among themselves, an iterative process was employed. After completing the calculation of initial values, the angular position of the crankshaft (θ) and its first derivative (θ·) were predicted by means of Taylor expansions as

In the same manner, φi, φ·i, yci and y·ci were predicted. After this, yi, ϒi, βi, ϑi, y·i, ϒ·i, β·i, ϑ·i, y··i, ϒ··i, β··i, ϑ··i, y···, ϒ…i, β…i, θ··i, θ…i, φ··i, φ…i, y··c and y…c were calculated iteratively using all of the relations derived in the analysis, and the numerical values required for the second time step were completed. The remainder of the numerical procedure is a repetition of the same operations. The magnitude of Δt may be determined by comparing the results from the stability point of view. When a cubic Taylor expansion, such as equation (32), is used, a time-step magnitude, Δt=1/5000, is found to be appropriate.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: Inputs were determined with a comprehensive study including literature investigations, experimental operations and theoretical approximations. Prior to this, approximate dimensions of the engine components were determined and solid models were depicted. The mass and inertial mass moment of the dynamic components were then determined by means of a design software. The ring-pack static friction force (F∞) was determined by measurement and found to be consistent with ones given by Guzzomi et al.27 The boundary friction coefficient of piston was taken from Ye et al.37 For the hydrodynamic friction, or hydrodynamic friction coefficient, of the piston, Dowson et al.34 suggested a Couette flow approximation. The hydrodynamic friction coefficient of the main bearings and big-end bearings of connecting rods were taken from Wang and Lim38 and Durak et al.39 The predictions made for the same bearings via Couette flow were also found to be comparable with Wang and Lim38 and Durak et al.39 The firing phase angle between the two pistons was taken to be 2π radians, which enables repetition of the power strokes with equal periods. The inputs used in the numerical applications are given in Table 2.

caption.p: Specific values used in the analysis.

sec.p: Variation of the nominal speed of the crankshaft and its periodic fluctuations versus the crankshaft rotation are illustrated in Figure 7. To obtain the curves given in Figure 7, a start-up moment of 50 Nm was applied within the range of crankshaft rotation 0≤θ≤1. When the engine started to run, as long as the external load is zero, the speed of the crankshaft continues to increase until the friction losses counterbalance the work generated by the working gas. When an external load is applied to the engine at any instant, after this the nominal speed of the crankshaft may either decrease, increase or remain constant according to the magnitude of the external load applied. By manipulating the external load, the nominal speed may be set to a constant speed. At lower constant values of the nominal speed of the crankshaft, the fluctuation of speed is larger. While the speed increases, the fluctuation displays a decelerating decrease, as seen in Figures 7 and 8. The moment generated by the engine, which is equal to the external load, decreases with crankshaft speed, which is due to hydrodynamic friction appearing on the piston and bearings. As seen in Figure 8, the decrease of the moment, with respect to the nominal speed of the crankshaft, displays a slight deceleration. This implies that the high-amplitude vibrations and crankshaft fluctuation appearing at low speeds have a slight influence on the moment of the engine. In Figure 8, the variation of the power versus the speed is also illustrated. The power exhibits a decelerating increase with speed, which is caused by the decrease in moment. Since the gas pressure function used in this analysis is independent of the engine speed, the torque and power curves seen in Figure 8 are very different from the practical situation.

caption.p: Variation of the crankshaft speed with rotation and load.
Variations of the crankshaft speed fluctuation and engine torque with average speed.

sec.p: While the combined inertia moment of rotating components increases (flywheel and crankshaft), the fluctuation exhibits a decelerating decrease. In this study, the combined inertia moment was optimized as 0.08 m2kg, which corresponds to 4% speed fluctuation at 3000 r/min nominal speed. For further reduction of the crankshaft speed fluctuation, a large increase in combined inertia is needed due to the decelerating decrease of the fluctuation.

The torsional vibration of the engine block is illustrated in Figure 9. Examinations were conducted by means of changing the values of several inputs. In this analysis, the starter motor is assumed to be mounted on the engine block and to have a considerable contribution to the initial rotational displacement of the block. The influence of the reciprocating masses was found to be insignificant. The principal source of the torsional vibration of the engine block was found to be working gas pressure. The minimized torsional vibrations appearing during stable running of the engine have about a 0.00125 radian amplitude. If the distance between the crankshaft centre and cylinder top is assumed to be 30 cm, there would be a 0.4 mm oscillation at the cylinder top. At initial vibrations, however, its value is approximately 18 mm. As seen from the magnified section in Figure 9, the curve is smooth and there are no secondary vibrations. When running under an external load, the engine block slants backward. Figure 9 indicates that the location of the dynamic equilibrium is at about 0.005 radian backwards from the static equilibrium point. This corresponds to a 1.5 mm displacement of the cylinder top.

caption.p: Torsional vibration of the engine block.

sec.p: The minimized translational vibrations of the engine block at transient and steady running conditions are illustrated in Figure 10 for a 75 kg block mass. The minimization of the translational vibration of the block is accomplished by means of adding counterweights opposite to the crank pins on the crankshaft. The amplitude of vibration appearing at the initial stage of the starting process is about 0.35 mm. The transient behaviours of the engine block end after four revolutions at most. The dynamic equilibrium of the block appears at 0.1 mm backward from the static equilibrium. The amplitude of the minimized translational vibration under the steady running conditions is about 0.1 mm, which is the lowest possible translational displacement and is obtained with a 700 g counterweight mass, which is equal to the sum of the piston mass and one-third of the connecting rod mass. As seen in Figure 10, at steady running conditions, the block exhibits vibrations at three different modes. The periods are π, 2π and 8π radians. The vibration with a 8π period is not very apparent.

caption.p: The translational vibrations of the engine block.

sec.p: As a result, a counterweight mass predicted by means of

is found to be appropriate for the minimization of the vertical vibration of the block induced by the inertia of reciprocating masses (piston mass plus one-third of the connecting rod mass). It is important that a counterweight added to the crankshaft opposite to the crank pin not only reduces the vertical vibration, but also generates a horizontal vibration of the same amplitude. Therefore, instead of using a counterweight to draw the vertical vibration to zero, using a counterweight to minimize both vibrations becomes imperative. For this purpose, half of the mass of the counterweight determined via equation (34) can be used, which minimizes both vibrations. In this paper, however, all of the numerical results were obtained for a 700 g counterweight by disregarding the horizontal vibration.

In Figure 11, the mount forces, appearing on mount A at steady running of the engine, are compared for k=250,000 and k=750,000 N/m stiffnesses. For a 750,000 N/m stiffness, the amplitude of the wave is 460 N, while it is 271 N for a 250,000 N/m stiffness.

caption.p: Comparison of mount forces obtained with two different spring stiffness.

sec.p: In Figure 12, the algebraic sum of the mount forces FA and FB is shown. The period of the resultant mount force is 4π radians. The period of the secondary fluctuation appears to be π radians. The periodic average of the resultant force is greater than zero, which is caused by translational displacement of the block.

caption.p: Variation of the sum of FA and FB.

sec.p: Figure 13 illustrates variation of the torque on the crankshaft at transient and steady conditions. The highest value of the torque appears in the start-up process, which is about 480 Nm. When the engine reaches its steady running speed and the external load is applied to the crankshaft, the torque of the crankshaft varies between 300 Nm and −200 Nm. The external torque applied to the crankshaft is 35 Nm, while the peak value of the torque appearing at steady running of the engine is 300 Nm, which is nine times higher than the external load. This result is a clear indication of crankshaft failure, which appears from time to time in diesel engines. As seen in Figure 13, the period of the main speed fluctuation of the crankshaft appears as 2π radians, which is caused by gas forces.

caption.p: Inertia torque variation on the crankshaft.

sec.p: Figure 14 illustrates the variation in the vertical displacement of the block versus the engine rotation speed. The graph was obtained with zero external load. Since the vertical vibration of the block is caused by the inertia force of the reciprocating parts, high-amplitude vibrations appearing below 20 Hz are not expected to decrease, even at the low gas positions of the engine. For this engine, an idling speed above 1200 r/min seems to be obligatory.

caption.p: Variation in vertical block displacement with engine speed.

sec.p: Figure 15 illustrates the fast Fourier transform spectrum of the mount force while the engine is running at 3000 r/min. Data used in this figure was obtained for a 250,000N/m spring constant. The amplitude of the spectrum is not scaled.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: A dynamic model was derived for a two-cylinder four-stroke engine and its dynamic behaviours were treated. The torsional and translational vibrations of the engine were found to be mainly induced by the gas forces and inertia forces of reciprocating masses, respectively. The combined inertia moment of the flywheel and crankshaft was found to be the dominant factor for reducing crankshaft speed fluctuations. The amplitudes of both the vertical and horizontal block vibrations may be adequately minimized by using a counterweight determined by

Under dynamic conditions, the position of the engine slightly differs from its static position. The inertia moment appearing on the crankshaft at transient and steady running of the engine is about 13 and 9 times the external load, respectively.
